III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS & CONCLUSIONS
A. Physical Description of Facility
Muskegon County Juvenile Transition Center was formerly licensed as a Child
Caring Institution (CCI), CE610366886. Muskegon Juvenile Transition Center
(MJTC) requested to close their CCI license and open under a Court Operated
Facility as the administrative authority was transferred from the Muskegon County
Board of Commissioners to the Muskegon County Family Court. This is 32 bed,
secure juvenile detention facility built in 2014. It is divided into two wings (A & B)
each wing consisting of two pods for a total of four pods – each able to
accommodate eight youth. Each pod consists of two single rooms and three double
rooms. Each room has an attached bathroom with locked door. Each of the pods is
able to accommodate a co-ed population, as census varies. Each room has the
ability to provide seclusion for one youth and is audio and video monitored.
The facility also has an intake and mental health assessment area, medical/dental
area, a family services and visitation area, three classrooms and a computer lab, a
gymnasium, a courtyard and outdoor recreation area, and two flexible living areas
that confine up to sixteen residents to a four room daytime living area. The facility
has a warming kitchen. Food is prepared off site and transported to the facility in
food warmers. Currently the facility contracts with Canteen Food Service. There is a
laundry area as well.
There is good visibility between areas that allows staff to view not only their own pod
group, but to observe other pod groups to insure orderly operation throughout the
facility. All doors in the facility are electronic, with staff carrying key fobs to open
doors. The four exterior doors in the facility are not controlled by these fobs. A shift
supervisor area allows all pods to be observed simultaneously via cameras. Exterior
doors are controlled by the shift supervisor.

An Environmental Health Inspection on 12/09/2016 resulted in an “A” rating, as did
the Fire Safety Inspection conducted on 12/22/2016.
B. Program Description
MJTC Mission Statement is “The Muskegon County Juvenile Transition Center
provides safety and security in a learning and caring environment”. The facility
serves youth ages 10-17 both male and female. The facility will address any
transgender youth based on the youth’s preference. The facility has many
community partners that help provide a continuum of care for youth while residing at
the facility and upon discharge including HealthWest (CMH), Muskegon Family Care
(for medical services), and Muskegon Area Intermediate School District.
According to their Policy and Procedure Manual the facility programming is as
follows:
The Muskegon County Juvenile Transition Center is a secure co-educational
facility which functions under the auspices of the Muskegon County Family Court.
Youth are referred to the Juvenile Transition Center by Family Court or one of its
designates. Only youth who are accused of or adjudicated for law violations are
placed in the facility. The facility assures that all legal rights of the youth are
protected while in custody and that confined youth live free from fear of assault or
intimidation by staff or other juveniles. Juvenile Transition Center personnel are
responsible for the care, guidance, and control of youth placed in their custody.
Youth are released only upon authorization of the Family Court or its designates.
The Muskegon County Juvenile Transition Center provides a short-term,
physically restrictive, safe, and humane environment for incarcerated youth. The
Muskegon County Juvenile Transition Center offers an individualized education
program that is qualified to meet special educational needs. All youth are
required to participate in the school program. Residents receive three nutritionally
balanced meals, an afternoon, and evening snack each day. The Juvenile
Transition Center provides a variety of recreational and physical activities which
are available to each resident. There is strong emphasis on individual and
communal hygiene and youth are required to shower daily, change clothing and
bedding often, and maintain their rooms in a clean and healthy manner.
The Juvenile Transition Center program components are designed to meet each
individual youth’s nutritional, emotional, spiritual, educational, recreational, and
physical needs.
Guided Group Interaction:
Guided Group Interaction uses this proactive approach in dealing with negative
behaviors. Residents are at the center of the program. They are the ones
responsible for dispensing advice, correction, and praise. This does not mean
that staff members give up complete control to the residents and dismiss
3

expectations, rules, and regulations. There are, and always will be, established
expectations and measures of discipline. Discipline will always be implemented
by staff. However, the program focuses on problem solving rather than problem
control. The underlying theory being that adolescents are naturally in an
oppositional phase of development, and thereby rejecting the advice and counsel
of adults in favor of that of their peers. In GGI, residents should perceive their
peer group as their primary source of help and support.
The staff’s most important role with regard to the program is to encourage, teach,
and guide the residents to help their peers in a caring and respectful manner. The
staff member role is NOT to control the residents but to teach the residents to
control themselves. When given proper direction, youth are not only willing to
help themselves, but also willing to help others. The group will function only as
well as the staff members develop them. As with individual growth and
development, the groups need firmly and sensitively set limits, encouragement,
and permission to make mistakes. Problems must be viewed as opportunities for
change.
Responding to Negative Behavior:
Residents are expected to “give help” in an appropriate manner when they
observe their peers behaving in a way that is against expectations. What does
“giving help” mean and what does it look like?
 Informal means of reminding or “cueing” a resident that their behavior is not in
line with program and facility expectations
 Informal means of offering suggestions to a resident to control his/her behavior
(time out, deep breathing, etc.)
 Must be done in a positive, helpful manner
 Should be done by residents!
 If residents are not taking responsibility for helping their peers, they may need
prompting – staff should only give help when they are the only one to witness
the behavior or the group is not functioning in a manner where they are being
helpful to each other.
For the most part, this informal means of reminding is sufficient to correct the
problem, at least temporarily. Occasionally, a resident doesn’t respond to help,
the behavior may continue or repeat even after several helps, or the behavior may
warrant something stronger than a help. It is in such instances that the formal
problem-solving process, Group Assistance, is used.
Group Assistance:
The Group Assistance (GA) process is the formal problem solving process used in
Guided Group Interaction (GGI). When a resident is not following expectations, a
group member or staff should offer them help by reminding them of expectations.
If a resident has not responded to help offered, a Group Assistance should be
called.
What is the purpose of a Group Assistance?
4

 Help residents understand and solve problem behavior
 Teach residents to take responsibility for their own actions
 Eliminate inappropriate behavior
 Build group cohesiveness
 Problem solve within the group
 Positively deal with behaviors immediately
 Behavior management
 Give residents opportunity to express themselves
 Give staff opportunity to show care and concern
 Help build staff trust and rapport with residents
 Opportunity to work on communication skills
 Encourage problem solving rather than problem control
A resident who has a GA called for him/her and works the GA positively, taking
responsibility for his/her behavior and coming up with a viable resolution, will be
considered to have “resolved” the GA – with no resulting consequence. If not, the
GA will be “unresolved”, and will result in a consequence, the severity of which is
based on the seriousness of the infraction as well as other considerations. In
theory and practice, the residents and staff must see the GA as a helping process,
and not as a punishment or a means of deciding punishment, or the process
breaks down. For this reason, one of the Youth Specialist’s main tasks is to
constantly teach and encourage the residents in the proper application of the
process. Teens being teens, there will naturally be many GAs. Ideally, the vast
majority of them will be resolved, as individual residents gain more insight not only
into the process, but also into their own behaviors.
Formal Group:
Formal group is held daily. It is a formal group setting where residents are to
discuss individual as well as group problems and successes. It is a time for the
group to discuss and resolve their issues. Residents are expected to assist each
other in problem solving and help each other understand the program. Care,
concern, and respect should always be practiced during this time. It is also a time
for residents to select a daily group goal and individual goals. Formal group is a
place where residents can express themselves appropriately and contribute to a
positive and safe group experience. Expectations for Formal Group are:
 Residents will recognize the group issues as well as their own
 Group members are expected to give and receive feedback in a caring and
respectful way
 Goals should be specific, meaningful, and related to program issues
 Residents are expected to participate and stay focused during this time
 Residents are expected to help solve individual as well as group problems
C. Rule/Statutory Violations
The agency is in compliance with all rules and statutes.
